Here is [an explanation of how I screen products](https://www.subject7996.com/articles/amazon-review-analysis). In many cases, my conclusions agree with Fakespot. Occasionally, a product will have an A-rating from Fakespot when I analyze the reviews it has at that point in time. A later influx of reviews can change the product's Fakespot rating without necessarily exposing any defects with the product itself. All of that said, it's best to trust your own judgement.

That's always an advisable thing to do. [My methodology for screening products](https://www.subject7996.com/articles/amazon-review-analysis) often jibes with Fakespot, but there are some outliers. I prefer to look Fakespot's adjusted rating rather than the letter grade. For example, if a product has a "D rating," it may have lots of bogus reviews, but if it still has a 4-star rating after accounting for those reviews, that's not such a bad thing.

There isn't much to it. Open the back of the camera (including the flap) and you can lay the sheet film flat on the focal plane. Close it back up and you're ready to shoot (assuming that you loaded in the dark and the emulsion is facing the right way). It's a single shot method, but it works. A lot of photographers also convert these cameras to accept 120 film. I haven't done that, but here is a thread: https://www.photo.net/discuss/threads/convert-your-polaroid-to-120-roll-film-and-enjoy-it.292146/
Silly as it sounds, I either load the film under my covers or in an interior room with the lights off.
Free. The 800 accepts 4x5 sheet film as is (one shot at a time, though). It's possible to convert the camera to accept 120 film, which costs around $5 and a little elbow grease.

I have a good macro lens and a light table, so I might photograph some stuff in quadrants and use the photostitcher in Photoshop to recombine the shots as 80MP or so. That said, [here's a shot](https://i.imgur.com/kvla129.jpg) that I just rephotographed against my desk lamp. The 800 has a surprisingly good lens, and when you get the exposure right with a film like Velvia or Provia, the colors really pop. You can also see the not-so-precise centering of the film as a result of laying it in the camera without a holder. Luckily, it stays flat (and in focus). On a side note, I had a heck of a time explaining my camera to Italian airport security. "Una macchina vecchia" as they liked to call it.

Before anyone knew what Tineye was, Getty was using something similar to send threatening letters and demand for payment for misused photos. I worked in a large publishing company at the time and we paid Getty handsomely to license images across our brands. Of the thousands of photos we used correctly, we used a handful that were exceptions to our license. They weren't anything special, just cheesy stock photos, yet Getty still demanded thousands of dollars in payment and threatened to take us to court over it. Since then, I've always told my employers to stay far away from Getty and its other properties. If that's how they treat paying clients...

These are fine points, but not applicable in the circumstances (which I didn't explain fully). The photographers were paid, albeit, something like $0.25 for the download, which is what they signed up for. The excess payment demanded by the agency was for the agency alone. We had a blanket subscription plan that allowed downloads across lots of photo collections (Thinkstock, Jupiter, etc.). One collection was not included, but was not specifically exempted either, and the photos were co-mingled with all the other search results that the writers had seen. In short, the photographers were paid via the terms they agreed to and my company was threatened to pay thousands of dollars for photos that were available for a $1 royalty free license elsewhere on the web. In the end, it was an abuse of power. (As an aside, I worked for years as a professional photographer and had my work misappropriated; I appreciate you taking the time to explain why this matters.)

Let me take another crack at this, though we may have to agree to disagree. We had a blanket royalty free subscription for our entire company. The writers searched directly on the Getty website for RF images. Over time, Getty dabbled with adding new RF images from places like Flickr, but there was no filter nor obvious distinction that those photos were outside our contract (which had defined the entire RF library at the time it was written). Among the thousands of images the writers downloaded, a handful of them were from the new sources and those were the ones we received $900 invoices for. The images used were available on other RF sites (like Dreamstime) for as little as $1 and without question, they were RF, not RM. Because our contract was written before those image sources were added to the Getty RF library, it didn't mention the source by name. (It's like the defining the U.S. in 1958 by listing each state by name. The next year, Hawaii and Alaska become states, but not in the eyes of documents written in 1958.) Had we taken the matter to court, I'm confident that it would have been thrown out as a bad faith claim. But that would have cost us more than the invoice, plus our time. That's why claims like that are so sinister, and I would argue, abusive.

I learned about those projects a few weeks ago: Both are amazing achievements! The dialogue issue I noticed is the opposite effect: The discrete center sounds *worse*. There's a distinction between a refund and return, even though a return usually results in a refund. In my case, I received an expired probiotic that couldn't be resold. I was given a refund. Five days later, the refund was converted into a return and a shipping label was created. I no longer had the product, so after the return window closed, I got stuck with the bill.

It's a case of whether they change their mind. I bought a non-returnable medical product that was expired when it arrived. I was given a refund with no indication to return the product, but five days later, I was sent a return shipping label.
I explained the situation, but they refused to refund me.

WRITING.TEXT: Good question. I give recent reviews more weight because factors like quality, shipping and customer service change over time. In this case, 3,923 of the Amazon reviews are either unverified or for a product version other than the one that is linked to above. This particular pen has [12 reviews](https://www.amazon.com/Cross-Classic-Century-Brushed-Ballpoint/product-reviews/B07P11DBP5/ref=cm_cr_getr_d_paging_btm_prev_1?ie=UTF8 amp;reviewerType=avp_only_reviews amp;pageNumber=1 amp;sortBy=recent amp;formatType=current_format amp;pldnSite=1) with a mean rating of around 3.8, which is right on the cusp of acceptability. What tipped the scale for me is that the pen typically sells for around $50...at around half price (which is the current deal), that 3.8 rating might skew higher for most people.

WRITING.TEXT: We had originally planned on making a patriotic cake, but because we only had a yellow cake mix in the house, [it came out more St. Patrick's like](https://i.imgur.com/Qahq2UB.jpg). Then we tossed some Christmas sprinkles on it to make it a real anachronism.
Thanks. I had originally planned to snake it through the wall, but my walls are made of 100-year old plaster that's more than an inch thick and the void behind it is narrow and filled with junk.

WRITING.TITLE: The power cord on my TV looks like it's connected to the microphone on the screen

WRITING.TEXT: Yes!

It's pretty great. The marketing fooled me a bit (I expected a matte image like an e-reader, but it's clearly a backlit image like a digital photo frame), but it looks nicer in a room than any TV I've seen. I once worked as a photographer; it's pretty awesome to see my work "framed" and in rotation. The picture quality is solid, but the automatic settings struggle with really dark shows like Ozark and as far as I can tell, there is no *completely* manual way to set the picture. I think it's a worthwhile purchase, but only when it's on sale.

OP here. I have 100-year old plaster walls that are more than an inch thick and the void behind them turned out to be incredibly narrow. (For context, there wasn't even enough room to flip a toggle bolt.) Because of the unpredictability of the wall and the fragility on that single cord (not to mention the $200 replacement cost!), I opted against running it in wall. Bummer.

Nice. We rent, so I'm reluctant to get adventurous with it. The plaster is so old that it's basically like concrete now, which is great for hanging stuff, but in collapses in certain spots. (Something I learned the hard way while running wire to my rear speakers.)

The first one may have been my fault because I rarely oiled it, but I pampered the second one. The third one was a warranty replacement for the second one (I treated that one with kid gloves, too). Though it pains me to say it, I've had much better luck with my AmazonBasics shredder. It's going on three years now.

Many, many times. But white ash is a more resilient wood than the hardwoods like maple. On the flip side, ash is considered to be a deader wood and may have fallen out of favor as a result.

The H12s have better noise cancellation (arguably, some of the best noise cancellation in sub $100 headphones), but they are more prone to failure than the H16s are. And all Mpow headphones are a little finnicky Bluetooth-wise. (The company is pretty good about refunds and replacements, though.) I was amazed to see that the H16s are selling for $14.99. That's 50% off the prior all-time low price!
I'm not a fan of Bluetooth audio, so I might opt for different headphones altogether. That said, a $15 pair of NC headphones with free returns is an interesting proposition.

I've [analyzed the reviews of both models](https://www.subject7996.com/articles/best-noise-cancelling-headphones), and while they each have their quirks and shortcomings, they're both a good value. Actually, those Sony's sometimes sell for as little as $17, which is really a bargain.

WRITING.TITLE: LPT: If you're not sure if an Amazon review is legitimate, copy the reviewer's photo and search for it within Google Images. In many cases, you'll find that the Amazon profile is bogus (i.e. using a misappropriated image from elsewhere on the web).
WRITING.TEXT: For example, ["Brook Jefferson"](https://reddit.com) has only left a single Amazon review for some knock-off AirPods, however, a Google Image search reveals that the woman in the picture is actually [named Jessica](https://womanshospital.com/whoisshe/stories/story-jessica). Hence, the Amazon review is phony.

Here are some additional ways to spot bogus listings: *5-star reviews should account for at least 45% of total reviews, but not more than 95%; *The combination of 4-star and 1-star reviews should amount to at least 5% of total reviews; and *When 3-star reviews outnumber 2-star reviews, or 2-star reviews outnumber 1-star reviews, it may imply that a product's acceptability is contingent upon comfort, user skill or a subjective factor, like personal taste. (In cases like these, it's a good idea to double-check the product's return policy). [Source](https://www.johnwdefeo.com/articles/amazon-review-analysis): (I'm a data scientist that specializes in analyzing user reviews.)

LPT: Log into your financial accounts at least once per year, particularly the ones that you don't think about often (like an old 401K). This prevents escheating, i.e. when the State Treasury claims money in a dormant account, then makes the owner jump through hoops to get it back.
WRITING.TEXT: This happened to me when my grandfather opened a college investment account in my name (when I was a minor). After a few years of inactivity, the state seized the account and it was a huge pain to get the money back.

I'm glad that they contacted you properly. It may sound cynical, but I can almost guarantee that states will be seizing assets more liberally now because of COVID-related budget shortfalls. (The same thing happened during the 2008/2009 financial crisis.)
:) That's what prompted me to research it in the first place.

It sounds like you need *low* thread-count sheets that are made from cotton. Synthetic fibers have a higher thermal resistance (that causes sweating); the higher the thread-count, the more the resistance increases. If you don't mind wrinkles, then a "percale" weave is probably the best value: They last for years and get softer with each wash. Look for a thread count under 300.

WRITING.TEXT: If you're open to the idea of used speakers, I'd argue that Rock Solid speakers (a low-end experiment of B amp;W) were the best budget bookshelf speakers ever made. Here is an eBay listing for context: https://www.ebay.com/itm/Pair-B-W-Rock-Solid-2-way-speakers-white-home-theater-Bowers-and-Wilkins/184402367531 - I can't vouch for the seller or those specific speakers, but I've had these since 1999 and they smoke everything I've compared them to.
A fair point. I felt like these rode the line because they aren't exactly "super cheap," at least in terms of quality. The MSRP was close to $300 when these were first released.

Also give the Definitive Technology ProMonitor 800s a look. They normally sell for $300 a pair, but they've sold for $160 a pair a few times recently. The matching ProCenter 1000 is pretty great, too.
That's the per speaker price, so $300 for the pair. That said, Amazon has been selling them for $80 each recently.

LPT: Saying "I feel __ when __" instead of "You're making me __" can diffuse many arguments before they even begin.
WRITING.TEXT: For example, if someone is hovering while you work, saying "You're making me nervous" can sound accusatory and put that person on the defensive. On the other hand, saying "I feel nervous when you're standing behind me" is an open and honest communication that doesn't imply wrongdoing by the other person. It's a small difference that can have a big impact on relationships.
Possibly, but it's also possible that the hoverer will perceive it as a passive-aggressive remark. *Distractions...I'm not doing anything, I'm just standing here. Jeez.*
